item.title: .NET MAUI in .NET 8 Preview 5 Available: Bug Fixes and Performance Improvements
item.description: NET MAUI in .NET 8 Preview 5 is available and contains bug fixes and performance improvements for cross-platform application development. It includes changes to iOS keyboard scrolling, test improvements, performance enhancements to the {Binding} mechanism and Android label layout. The announcement provoked different emotions in the community.
item.author:
(Robert Krzaczyński
Software EngineerFollow)

item.title: Value Objects in C# - Code Maze
item.description: In this article, we explore Value Objects in C#. We discuss when and why we should use them, as well as looking at some of the drawbacks.
item.author: (Code Maze)

item.title: Episode 125 - Mixed Reality, the Metaverse, and Making Magic Happen with Simon Jackson
item.description: Simon Jackson, a Microsoft Global MVP for mixed reality, shares his expertise on the future of software development in mixed reality and the metaverse. He highlights the importance of accessibility, AI integration, and choosing the right technology to build successful virtual and augmented reality experiences. Jackson also shares inspiring examples of how mixed reality can positively impact industries such as healthcare and education, and discusses his own work on creating augmented museum experiences. This podcast is a must-listen for anyone interested in the future of technology and its potential for positive change.

item.title: Dart Sass and Hugo Themes
item.description: Quick notes on variables, dart-sass and hugo Background Recently I decided that it was annoying for me as a user to not know which links on my site were internal and which led off to an external site. Figure 1: The desired end-result, blue for internal links, purple for external links, colors chosen with ColorHexa However, since hugo requires baseurl for generating meaningful rss and sitemap files, this meant either hardcoding the variable into my theme, or figuring out how to pass variables from my config.
item.author: ([Rohit Goswami])

item.title: You don't take enough risks to be lucky
item.description: I quit my job a month ago, which will probably end up among the best turning points of my career. To be clear, there was nothing wrong with that job, the alternative is just that much better. My social and professional networks have grown dramatically. I have the most intellectual

item.title: Developer Brethren, its Time to Embrace Boring!
item.description: So this morning I was listening to one of the Linux related podcasts, Coder Radio and the hosts read feedback from a listener who claimed that he was &quot;bored&quot; with PHP and ready to try something else. Now to be fair, in this particular case, the writer outlined some circumstances that made me sympathize with him. Long story short is that parts of the PHP based stack he was relying on for some of his software had changed significantly. In order to update his software to a currently supported version of PHP, he basically now has to rewrite it from scratch. So yeah, that sucks.
item.author: (Jay Little)

item.title: 6 Reasons You Don't Need an SRE Team
item.description: The last several years have seen a huge upsurge in the popularity of the DevOps/SRE/Production Engineering model, with companies large and small adopting some of the practices and mindsets. One of the principal lessons many of these organisations (hopefully) learned was that it's close to impossible to adopt the SRE model as described by Google in the the first SRE book. It's a good approach to take on board the parts of the book that work for you, and to actively triage your time, energy and effort.

item.title: Why use Azure OpenAI when you have OpenAI?
item.description: In addition to the ChatGPT application, OpenAI has also released APIs that allow you to integrate it in your products. Confusingly, Microsoft has also released something called Azure OpenAI Service, which appears to be doing the same.
item.author: (Sheshbabu Chinnakonda)
